prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have configured the correlator using 2 GHz bands when no interesting lines are present, tailored the rest to obtain the best combination of continuum sensitivity and velocity resolution.
We are maximizing our surface brightness sensitivity by going for the most compact configuration, C36-1.

We employ two setups for each of our two sources: 1) a setup in band 3 to map the CO (1-0) emission in each region over the area of the dust emission (from LABOCA and Herschel images), with the band on the CO line at high resolution (0.16 km/s) resolution and the rest in continuum mode to maximize our sensitivity to free-free emission. 2) A setup in band 6 mapping CO (2-1) and continuum emission, while simultaneously observing C18O (2-1) over the same area. Both setups use the ACA+TP in order to recover all extended spatial information for lines, and spatial structures up to 44" and 19" in continuum emission for B3 and B6 respectively (assuming that the delivered TP is not stable enough to provide some measure of the continuum, which it may).
Line sensitivity: Our B3 observations have a sensitivity goal of 0.2 K brightness temperature in a 3.4" beam in 0.5 km/s channels. The lines detected in MagBridge A in cycle 1 are narrow, and our goal is to recover kinematic information. At the spatial resolution of ~1 pc we should be resolving the molecular cloud, thus we expect intrinsic 12CO brightness of 3-4K (and indeed, that is approximately true for the observed cycle 1 MagBridge A source). Thus, we should have S/N of 30-40 in several 0.5 km/s channels.
Continuum sensitivity: In the B3 observations will will reach a continuum sensitivity ~300 uJy, sufficient to see the free-free emission due to a B star at the distance of the SMC. Here we assume we will see ~1 mJy due to a young cluster.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum 1mm, CO 2-1 in MagBridge B
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Dust continuum and CO 2-1/C18O 2-1 Sadly no 13CO possible without sacrificing the continuum sensitivity significantly

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have configured the correlator using 2 GHz bands when no interesting lines are present, tailored the rest to obtain the best combination of continuum sensitivity and velocity resolution.

We have used TDM windows whenever possible. The lines will be narrow (~2-3 km/s), so 0.3 km/s for 12CO and 1.3 for C18O is already a compromise. The data rate is only a few percent higher than the nominal maximum.
We are maximizing our surface brightness sensitivity by going for the most compact configuration, C36-1.

Our B6 observations will reach a line sensitivity of 0.25 K in 1.6" in 1 km/s channels. If the 12CO emission is optically thick and thermalized, our S/N should again be ~30-40.
Our continuum sensitivity in the B6 observations will be ~150 uJy. The LABOCA map of this region indicates a flux at 345 GHz of ~20 mJy per 22.5" beam over several beams, which translates into ~5 mJy integrated at 225 GHz assuming a $\beta$=1.5 emissivity exponent --- this is likely an underestimate, since the emissivity is anomalous, and we indeed see "brighter than expected" emission in the MagBridge A source mapped by ALMA. If the emission were completely smooth over the LABOCA beam, which is very unlikely, we would not detect it in an individual synthesized beam at 1.6". But the emission is very likely clumpy (our number assumes a filling fraction of 5% of the LABOCA beam), and ACA does recover scales up to 19" which will allow us to average over one LABOCA beam.
Our B6 continuum sensitivity corresponds to a dust optical depth sensitivity tau~0.7e-4 assuming 30 K dust. This can be translated into a physical column density assuming a Galactic dust emissivity per H nucleon, C~3.2e-27 cm2/H (Draine 2003), yielding N(H2)~1e22 1/cm2 (i.e., molecular). Although this assumes a Galactic dust-to-gas ratio, because this region seems to have an anomalously high emissivity it is likely the sensitivity will not be very different from this number by factors of a few. But finding out this number is one of the reason for the observations.
See previous B3 science goal. The experimental design is identical.
See previous B3 science goal. The experimental design is identical.
See previous B3 science goal. The experimental design is identical.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum 1mm, CO 2-1 in MagBridge C
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Dust continuum and CO 2-1/C18O 2-1 Sadly no 13CO possible without sacrificing the continuum sensitivity significantly

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: See justification in previous B6 science goal. The experimental design is identical.
See justification in previous B6 science goal. The experimental design is identical.
See justification in previous B6 science goal. The experimental design is identical.

Our B6 observations will reach a line sensitivity of 0.25 K in 1.6" in 1 km/s channels. If the 12CO emission is optically thick and thermalized, our S/N should again be ~30-40.
Our continuum sensitivity in the B6 observations will be ~100 uJy. The LABOCA map of this region indicates a flux at 345 GHz of ~6-10 mJy per 22.5" beam over several beams, which translates into ~1.5-2.5 mJy integrated at 225 GHz assuming a $\beta$=1.5 emissivity exponent --- this is likely an underestimate, since the emissivity is anomalous, and we indeed see "brighter than expected" emission in the MagBridge A source mapped by ALMA. If the emission were completely smooth over the LABOCA beam, which is very unlikely, we would not detect it in an individual synthesized beam at 1.6". But the emission is very likely clumpy (we assume ~3%-5% of the LABOCA beam), and ACA does recover scales up to 19" which will allow us to average over one LABOCA beam.
Our B6 continuum sensitivity corresponds to a dust optical depth sensitivity tau~0.7e-4 assuming 30 K dust. This can be translated into a physical column density assuming a Galactic dust emissivity per H nucleon, C~3.2e-27 cm2/H (Draine 2003), yielding N(H2)~1e22 1/cm2 (i.e., molecular). Although this assumes a Galactic dust-to-gas ratio, because this region seems to have an anomalously high emissivity it is likely the sensitivity will not be very different from this number by factors of a few. But finding out this number is one of the reason for the observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Magellanic Bridge is a filamentary structure of about 15 to 21 kpc seen in neutral hydrogen (HI) lying between the LMC and the SMC. It represent the nearest tidally interaction between these two galaxies some 200 Myr ago. It hasa lower metallicity than the SMC and therefore allow to study the ISM in extreme conditions. Recent studies have revealed the presence of young (< 200Myr) massive stars and CO molecular clouds. The latter are barely resolved in single-dish observations and are spatially related to warm dust emissionsources, as recently established by the Spitzer SMC-SAGE and Herschel HERITAGE studies. We have obtained 870 micron images of three these sources in the Magellanic Bridge. Surprisingly, their dust emission shows a large submillimeter excess indicative of either very cold dust or a dramatically different submillimeter emissivity. Source A was observed in ALMA c1 and shows an excess at 1mm and several CO cores. We propose to study two additional sources in CO(1-0) and (2-1) and the associated continuum at arcsecond resolution to determine the physical properties of molecular cloud which are in a different evolutionary stage than Sourcce A.
